comments.commentBody: The outrage comes not from purely the image of another slain youth lying in the streets, the frustration begins when there is a trend that reflects that the slaughter of this young man will go unpunished. No one has failed to mention that black on black crime is not a rare occurrence yet there has been no mention to the fact that white on white crime is just a prevalent, if not more. The militarized police force that we have grown in the US no longer wishes to deescalate an issue, instead they quickest end is now the preferred method. A young man died, no matter his color or background, and there will be no release of the name of the reaper of his life, and just as likely is the punishment.
Howie, I thought it wouldn't be good to mislead anyone.  LB was a NYC gal, so I knew you knew.

When that happens, the killer goes to jail.

The outrage is precisely BECAUSE it's done by a cop. A public servant we PAY and give authority. And who uses it to harm those he is being paid to protect.

And who receives NO PENALTY for the killing.

Do you actually not get that?
Hillary is the Democrats' John McCain in many ways, from her propensity for war as a solution to everything, to her age, to her out-of-date policies.

[Without their industrious and creative drive, we would be poorer as a nation...]

Yes, we would. Since Southern whites didn't know how to plant their own crops, cook their own food, fix their own stuff, or clean their own houses.

Yes, If you use them to represent a population, they are a misrepresetation as well. Why are the pictures and videos representative of anything but the events captured?
Additionally: Is it that difficult to say that this characterization is wrong, without also saying it is deserved?

John, You've apparently gone and dove headlong into the DEEPENDS! Oops! It looks like I've jumped the gun myself, by over eagerly submitting a comment on tonight's blog that will be delayed, according to Deb's earlier blog alert in blue, until early tomorrow morning...My bad!

Howie

@urbanculturescholar Exactly my point. Somewhere thuggin is me being sarcastic. I'm making reference to the article at hand. Commentary of the media perceives African Americans as thugs or harmful by there appearance. Just as the teens are making their point on twitter with pictures, I am a black college student in reality but according to spectators I am probably on the streets thuggin

To address others that have gotten off subject! Did I not ask for help on correct information so that my point remained valid ? @MAidO'Han was the only person that commented under my post who actually had correct information for me to attain. Am not going on a rant about black on black crime, Jewish graduate rates or my ability to know the difference in using do or due, because none of your comments have to do with the article at hand. If you are looking for a person to be combative or argumentative about subjects that don't pertain to the original article than let me inform you that i have a watch but I don't have time.

George,
I don't think you quite understood the point of the comment. Try reading it again, a little slower.

M., you have a lot to say with a lot of passion. And you are right! That's what we get to do in our country.
Tell me this; what purpose was accomplished with rioting and looting over this young man's death?
Tell me this: why didn't our country riot when body bags from Iraq started coming home?
Tell me this; is there one answer to fit all of the modes of behavior some choose to use and how does one contain anti-society options?
We all would like the questions answered and more but it takes a long time to explain why some apply rage so differently with each event.

You are correct that race should be removed from the conversation, and that some police officers actions are unwarranted and at times even illegal, but you are wrong when you say that if an unarmed man is shot that it is unequivocally murder. If that unarmed man is attacking an armed citizen who genuinely fears for his or her life that citizen is acting in self-defense should they use their firearm to protect themselves. That is not murder, but it is legally justified homicide.  We need to let the investigation continue and when we have all the facts and evidence only then should we make a judgment on the actions of those involved.

This has nothing to do with the article more so on the comments... I agree that race should be taken out of the equation. Most of the comments that I have read in response to this story have been formed around race. The absolute truth is that no one has the right to judge anyone else. The root of the problem is the stereotypes held by some in one race about another race. It's all about perception people, some of you are supporting the stance that he asked for it because he dressed a certain way but what did his actions show? I also believe that some police officers indeed throw their power and use it in ways that are unjust. My definition of justice is that the punishment for any horrendous act towards another person(s) or property is equal to the crime. If you shoot an unarmed man you have committed some form of murder. If you have stolen from someone then you are thief and should be punished as such regardless of race. People should be judge by their actions only. Although this is not the thought process of our current society, the change starts with one. It's always easier to point out the should of, could of, would of's for others but its way harder to turn that mirror on yourself. Take a good look at your own prejudices and stereotypes and then put them to the test and see how many turn up empty and without proper cause. Change starts in the heart of the people.

John, my personal inclination would be to go with Cleopatra's suicide, though that might make suejean snatch me bald-headed.

Also, given what-all we've learned from AlanJ about the calendar's history, that date might not be entirely accurate.

This argument is difficult to credit, coming from Bad Hamburg, Germany - representative government courtesy of United States military action - including long-term occupation and extended military presence.

Iraq, in its complicated history, has been a parliamentary democracy longer than any part of Germany before 1945.

The current peaceful transition of power is a clear refutation of your entire, borderline racist analysis.

You said it. They need "A Leader", not a party of leaders. Regardless of who is put in that democratic position, the truth is the people of Iraq will not tolerate it. Despite the U.S. and U.N.'s insistence on WMD's in Iraq, the country was better off with a dictatorship. It was better off with Saddam in power. Not only did he keep the country together, but he kept groups such as ISIS at bay. Now any retaliation by the west will see a new wave of terrorism conducted in those countries such as Australia and the U.S. This situation has been poorly handled by all involved. Leaders do not let their people die. The U.S. handed power to a person who was worthless in his aims and motives, and look at the country now. It has been handed to a network that is worth billions and they can move as they like between two countries. The U.S. wanted this.

Let's see...

Fruitland Florida: Police chief and deputy resign when it was discovered they were members of the KKK. http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/21/police-ku-klux-klan-florida...

Young man shot by the LAPD. Family says he was on the ground and complying http://ktla.com/2014/08/12/man-hospitalized-after-being-shot-by-police-i...

‘He Tried to Kill Me': Marlene Pinnock Opens Up About CHP Beating Caught on Video
http://ktla.com/2014/08/10/he-tried-to-kill-me-marlene-pinnock-opens-up-...

Steven Eugene Washington was shot and killed by LAPD officers. He had Autism (his is only one of several similar cases)
http://tinyurl.com/msh62s3

Kendrec McDade: Pasadena to withhold part of report on police shooting
http://tinyurl.com/ny5omfg

There are many, many more. Something is terribly wrong with who police departments hire, how they are trained, and how they conduct themselves.

It's patently absurd to claim that replacing Maliki with Abadi, someone else from his Dawa Party, will usher in a new era of reconciliation in Iraq. The skies won't open and ISIS Sunnis won't lay down their arms. This is just window dressing. Americans are being lied into a new open-ended military and financial commitment in Iraq.

The conservative deficit hawks and the liberals who call for domestic social spending are notably quiet.
Thank you
He may have been duly elected but he is also being constitutionally replaced as the article points out however obscurely.

"He has also lost a great deal of support among ordinary Iraqis, many of whom were gleeful on Tuesday at Mr. Maliki’s apparent downfall, and many of them credited the United States with engineering his ouster."

This sounds vaguely reminiscent of Bush war propaganda. "The Iraqis love us and credit us". The evidence? Not the election results which favor Maliki. Not a poll. Instead, we're offered Maliki's old ex-tailor in Baghdad, who's upset about Maliki's new found love for "Italian suits".

We've been fed the same amateurish lines about Saddam and his love for expensive suits. Islamic clothing or Italian suits, Arab leaders can't win. Perhaps they should consider Brooks Brothers, mid-priced suits for the aspiring Arab leader.
The President of Iraq had the rights replace him.  His attempt to hold on to power makes it clear he is unfit to hold office in even a fledgling democracy like Iraq.

I propose a 2 sided test, anyone can do this in a spreadsheet.

1000 trials of Blacks (Africans and otherwise) no antibody intervention.
X + 3 known trials of Europeans (continental and otherwise), 3 known antibody interventions.

If the NYT reporter can tell us X (zero?) excel will tell whether these have been shown to be two distinct populations, and produce the probability that they are different.

If they are different and the probably is significant, you can treat any justifications (such as severally offered by subjects in this article) for any results of any individual trial that conforms with its population as noise.

Your anecdote doesn't seem comparable. As many posters have said, a patient-centered response in which the doctors merely asked the Dr. would have been highly appropriate.

Dr. Khan was accustomed to practicing and making decisions in the situation you describe. The environment makes little difference, really -- unless they were all in a panic. And perhaps, to some extent, they are and have been.

It's been widely reported that there were hardly more than a dozen doses of ZMapp. This is stuff being "manufactured" by a 9-person lab in San Diego. So it can hardly be "deployed" to save the lives of more than a handful of people.

The goal of triage is to save as many people as possible with limited resources.  Doctors believed that Dr. Khan's viral levels were too high for ZMapp to work.  Giving it to him would have wasted one of only five doses of a potentially life-saving treatment.  In triage, you prioritize the patients who you can do the most good for -- which sometimes means not trying to save those with a small chance of survival.  Sometimes that can seem heartless and cruel, but it saves lives.

It's been acknowledged that the experimental drug developed and made in America was not specifically put aside for future use by citizens of America.  That said, the lives of the two American missionary workers were certainly no less valuable than that of any of the other human beings suffering with ebola,  and the missionaries were actively devoting every resource available (physical, mental, emotional, financial, etc.) to attempt to help those most in need--free gratis.  For God's sake, please stop apologizing and/or offering uncalled for, asinine excuses to the American public and to the rest of the world for daring to save the lives of two freaking American citizens with the technology and expertise of their own darned country.  It's absolutely absurd.

Hillary doesn't have to channel John McCain to take cheap shots. She's so ready to prove that she has the ability to make war that it makes W's need to best his daddy pale in comparison.

No thanks.
